But we know enough about where the meme grew up to say that these statistics can't be trusted. We looked into the news, quarterly profiles of congressional membership and other sources, and found nowhere near 84 arrests for drunk driving, 14 arrests for drugs, 36 accusations of spousal abuse or any of these other charges. We're not even sure how to measure things like an indirect business bankruptcy or someone's conviction. Capitol Hill Blue had many credible cases in the past. Remember, if these statistics are correct - and we are reasonably certain that they are not - they are 15 years old. Only 100 members of the current Congress were in office in 1999, when Capitol Hill Blue published these stories. According to Capitol Hill Blue, authors ' research revealed each of the above statistics, although at times in a slightly different format. (Except one, the article states that 29 members were charged with ill-treatment of the husband rather than 36 members.) The authors state "public records, previous press articles, civil court cases and criminal records," but do not cite specific documents. They also clearly say from some of their sources, "We have spoken to former partners and business partners who were excluded in the cold by people who thought they were friends." So these sources may have had an agenda to talk to Blue Capitol Hill. We can't even check out the congressmen they're talking about.
